climbs.name: Zinging in the Grain
climbs.fa: Peggy Buckey, Todd Swain, Randy Schenkel & Andy Schenkel, December 1988

content.description:
Climb a short crack/flake, then face past a rusty bolt.

Anchors present a problem. A couple large cams in a flared groove might work, or a 20' sling around a protrusion.

More suitable anchors can be found further back.

Descend third class to the right.
content.protection: Pro to 1", Big cams for possible anchors.
content.location: This route is at the southeast end of the main formation.

climbs.name: Whole Grain Goodness
climbs.fa: Alan Bartlett, Chris Miller and Jim Hammerle, November 1993

content.description: Decent hand and fist crack that's grainy like everything else in the area.
content.location:
Grainy crack between

Zinging in the Grain

and

Phantom Tollbooth

.

content.description:
This is the bolted line just left of Mother of All Poodles. There are two options on this route. Directly up at the first bolt to a strenuous mantle goes at mid-upper 10 for the move. Otherwise, it's possible to move to the right on part of M.O.A.P, then head back up and left to the second bolt. 5.8 but runout.

East facing.
content.location: Heading toward grain central station from the road, it can be seen as the low angle slabby rock about 1/4 the length of the formation from the right.

content.description:
This climb is at the northwest side of the formation.

Climb the left leaning crack on the left side.

Descend third class.

climbs.name: Snoops
climbs.fa: Mark Maynard and Allen Anderson, November 1989

content.description: This is a short, steep, exposed, clean face.
content.location: 75 feet right of B.M.T.C. Leader is another protruding buttress.  One bolt marks this climb.

climbs.name: Phantom Tollbooth
climbs.fa: (TR) Pat Brennan et al., FL: Chris Miller, Jim Hammerle & Alan Bartlett, November 1993

content.description: Start up a white slab to gain a steep and featured brown face where engaging climbing past three bolts leads to a wide crack finish out left. Belay on top and walk off to climber's left.
content.location:
Around and right from

Zinging in the Grain

in a northeast-facing cove.

climbs.name: Mother of All Poodles
climbs.fa: George Zelenz and Chris Miller, November 1993

content.description: This generic grainy slab climbs lumpy face to a ledge with a bolt and then continues to the top via more grain.
content.protection: One hangerless bolt (1/4") with a washer, gear to 2.5 inches for anchor
content.location:
South face of Grain Central Station, on a short slab facing east that lies just left and around the corner from

Zinging in the Grain

.

content.description:
This route follows a seam/water runnel and after an initial lower-angled section it steepens for the finish.

While not especially well protected it does make for a fun solo.
content.location:
Located 50 meters north of

Zinging in the Grain

at the mouth of a cove; the route faces southeast.

content.description:
Ascend a ramp that leads up and left to a steep corner, passing a shallow round hollow on the right face near the top.

Could do the direct start up the bottom of that dihedral system, if the catclaws someday no longer block that.

This route is listed in the Bartlett Indian Cove book.
content.protection: Med cams to big #4, gear anchor.
content.location:
Located about 50 ft right of Dancing On Dimes.

The left one of two steep corners on the right end of that longer wall, left of and around the corner from Zinging In The Grain.

Walk off the backside (east face) via slopey down scrambling.

content.description: The name says it all. Its pretty short. The rock here on this slab is not that bad.
content.protection: 3 bolts to 2 bolt anchor with rap rings
content.location: This route is on the SW corner of the formation. The start is tucked in a little alcove.

climbs.name: B.M.T.C. Leader
climbs.fa: Warren Mellinger, Dan Newman, and Ben Chapman, April 1986

content.description: A fun overhanging start (crux) leads to a steep hand traverse.  Above is a clean friction face (no bolts, but it's not hard).
content.location: This goes up the right side of a detached flake.

content.description:
This is a shallow right-facing corner system guaranteed to flay your flesh.

Make sure to tape up or bleed!
content.location:
40 feet left of

The Grain Mutiny

and starting from behind a giant brown boulder.

content.description:
Even grittier than it's neighbor, this route starts from a cave and tunnels upwards toward the light to reach a gritty crack soaring skyward.

Make sure to tape up or bleed!
content.location:
Twenty feet left of

30 Grit Route

.
